quests.name: It's Been Five Thousand Years
quests.description: The Certus Quartz Wrench, as I assume you've noticed, is wayyy harder to make in Expert mode than usual. When used in recipes, you get the Certus Quartz Wrench back, so don't be afraid to use it.

tasks.longDescription: The Certus Quartz Wrench requires 2 Enhanced Galgadorian Metal (54 Brown Mushrooms, 56 Obsidian, 9 Diamond Blocks, 25 Iron Bars, 14 more Diamonds, 26 Iron Ingots, 27 Glowstone Dust, 54 Sugar, 27 Ender Pearls, 8 Blaze Rods, 54 Ghast Tears, 54 Spider Eyes, 108 Magma Cream), and 2 Enhanced Sunnarium Alloy (64 Uranium, 64 Glowstone Blocks, 10 Sunnarium, 16 Iridium Reinforced Plates).

quests.name: Energy Conversion
quests.description: An ME System does not use RF or EU, but AE. You can convert RF and EU into AE by connecting it into the Enegy Acceptor and piping it out with Fluix Cables. You can also supply power through the ME Controller, but then that is one less side you can pull channels from.

tasks.longDescription: 1EU = 2 AE. 1 AE = 2 RF.

quests.name: So Many Channels, Nothing On
quests.description: The ME Controller gives you more channels to work with. Each side adds 8 or 32 channels. It can also accept energy and convert it to AE. It is a multiblock, and you can only have one per ME System.
prerequisites: {It's Like a Whole New Game}[Wait, HOW Long?!?!]

tasks.longDescription: The ME Controller also accepts RF and EU to power the ME system, but that is one less side you can use channels with.

quests.name: Made Out of Buttons and Wires
quests.description: AE2 machines are hooked up and powered via Fluix conduits. Channels are a very special mechanic: most Busses or AE2 Machines take up a channel. Different cables have different amounts of channels available.

tasks.longDescription: ME Glass Cables can only carry 8 channels. You can connect Busses to them.
ME Smart Cables can also only hold 8 Channels at once, but you see a visual representation of them. You can hook up Busses with them also.
ME Dense Cables can carry 32 channels, and you can see a visual representation of them. However, you cannot connect Busses to them.

quests.name: ME Conduits
quests.description: These Conduits can fit in the same block as other Ender IO Conduits. They cannot connect to Busses or Panels.
prerequisites: Made Out of Buttons and Wires

tasks.longDescription: ME Conduits carries 8 channels.
Dense ME Conduits carry 32 channels.

quests.name: ME Wire Coils
quests.description: These Wire Coils function similar to other Wire Coils from Immersive Engineering.
prerequisites: Made Out of Buttons and Wires

tasks.longDescription: Touch ME Cables to the ME Transformer, then connect via ME Wire Connectors and Fluix Wire Coils to another ME Transformer and the rest of your ME System. This tier can only hold 8 channels, and can have 24 blocks inbetween ME Wire Connectors.

Touch ME Cables to the ME Dense Transformer, then connect via ME Dense Wire Connectors and Dense Wire Coils to another ME Dense Transformer and the rest of your ME System. This tier can hold 32 channels, and can have 16 blocks inbetween ME Dense Wire Connectors.

quests.name: Not Actually Floppy
quests.description: Storage Cells are placed into the ME Drive. Every Storage Cell can only take 63 unique items, but the different tiers can hold certain amounts of bytes. 8 items take up 1 byte, no matter the size of a regular stack. Going straight for the max size Storage Cell isn't necessarily the best idea, because then you still only have 63 possible unique items, even if it's a lot more of those 63 items.
prerequisites: Made Out of Buttons and Wires

tasks.longDescription: I won't ask you to make any specific Storage Cell, as depending on where you are you can afford larger ones.

quests.name: Accessing Your Stuff
quests.description: The ME Crafting Terminal allows you to access items stored in your ME Storage Cells, and has an in-built crafting table.
prerequisites: Made Out of Buttons and Wires

tasks.longDescription: The ME Crafting Terminal connects to an ME Cable, and takes up 1 channel.

quests.name: The Wheels on the Bus
quests.description: No, not that kind of bus. These Busses are essentially ways to interact with things outside of the ME System. These all take a channel each.
prerequisites: Made Out of Buttons and Wires

tasks.longDescription: The Import Bus pulls items from an inventory in front of it into the ME System it is connected to. For example, if you want to move all your items out of chests into your ME System, you would use a Dolly to move all your chests so that they're connected to an Import Bus, which will suck out all the items and put them into the System. You can set a whitelist on what to import by opening it and putting items into it. By default, the whitelist can only have 1. With 2 Capacity Cards, it can have 9.

The Export Bus pushes items out of the ME System into the inventory it is facing. You have to open the Bus and put the items you want to push out into it. Without Capacity Cards, you only can export 1 item. With 2 Capacity Cards, you can export 9.

The Storage Bus allows you to access inventories that are not a part of the ME system. If you place it facing, for instance, a Drawer Controller, you won't have to get rid of your entire wall of Drawers; instead, you'll be able to access them all from ME Terminals. This way, you won't waste precious Storage Cell space.

quests.name: Autocrafting
quests.description: AE2's probably best feature is Autocrafting. This allows you to automatically craft whatever you define, which saves a surprising amount of time.
prerequisites: Made Out of Buttons and Wires

tasks.longDescription: The Crafting CPU is a multiblock. It must be a cuboid, meaning it has 6 sides maximum. It is made up of Crafting Co-Processing Units and Crafting Storages. The more Crafting CPUs, the faster it can craft things (so long as they don't require outside machines, which can only be sped up with their own mechanics). The more Crafting Storage you have, the more complicated of a recipe you can make. Having multiple Multiblocks allows you to autocraft multiple things at once.

The ME Pattern Terminal allows you to set recipes that can be autocrafted, either through regular crafting or through machines. You need Blank Patterns to begin with. For crafting table recipes, input the recipe to the crafting table gui to the left and hit the Encode Pattern Button and pull out the Encoded Pattern. For processing patterns, for instance Alloy Smelter or other things like that, click the Crafting Table to the right to switch modes. Then, put the inputs to the left and outputs to the right. Keep clicking to put more of the same item in if you need multiple or recieve multiple of one of the items.

The ME Interface is where you connect your ME System to processing or crafting. For processing, put the ME Interface (preferably the panel version, as you can put multiple in one block, and you specify which side of the cable) next to a machine, like an Alloy Smelter. Then, put a processing recipe into the bottom slots of the ME Interface. Connect an Import Bus to the machine to pull the finished item back into the ME System. Bingo presto! Automatic processing! For regular crafting, see the next task. ME Interfaces take up a channel each.

The Molecular Assembler, aside from being the freaking best looking block in the entire game, is how you autocraft regular crafting recipes. You can put several next to each ME Interface. The ME Interface touching them is where you put the regular Encoded Patterns into. You don't need to set up Import Busses, as the Molecular Assembler puts the items back into the ME System when crafted.

quests.name: Dimensional Box
quests.description: The ME Wireless Access Point and Wireless Terminal allow you to wirelessly access your ME System's items.
prerequisites: Made Out of Buttons and Wires

tasks.longDescription: The ME Wireless Access Point is the central location that you have to be nearby to in order to use the Wireless Terminal. You can extend the range with Wireless Boosters at the cost of more AE/t usage.
The ME Security Terminal is how you bind your Wireless Terminal to the ME System. Place the Wireless Terminal in the top right and it will bind to that system.
The Wireless Terminal is essentially an ME Access Terminal that you can hold.

quests.name: MagiTech Crafting
quests.description: The Arcane Crafting Terminal works as a regular Crafting Terminal AND an Arcane Worktable. You put your Wand in there, and craft like normal, but you have access to your entire ME System while doing it.

quests.name: Electric Fluids
quests.description: The ME Fluid Terminal allows you to access fluids in your ME System. You need to have Fluid Storage in your ME System to store fluids in it.

tasks.longDescription: Put the thing you want to put the fluid into (bucket/can/whatever) into the left slot, and click what you want to put into it. Or, you can put a filled fluid container into the left slot, and it will go into the system.

quests.name: Now With USB3 Compatibility
quests.description: The Wireless Universal Terminal has different modes depending on what you craft together. To switch modes, shift right click it.

tasks.longDescription: To add a mode, craft a Wireless Terminal with an Access Terminal that you want to add support for. To make the max upgraded one, craft the regular Wireless Access Terminal with either a Fluid Terminal or Essentia Terminal, and then craft that with the other one.

quests.name: Information MagiTechnology
quests.description: The Essentia Terminal allows you to access Essentia in your ME System. To store Essentia in your ME System, you need Essentia Storage Cells.

quests.name: Amphibious Bus Tour
quests.description: These Busses work exactly the same as the regular ones, but with Fluids.

quests.name: Magic School Bus
quests.description: These Busses work exactly the same as the regular ones, but with Essentia.

quests.name: Magical Autocrafting
quests.description: With these machines you will be able to automatically craft things that usually would require an Arcane Worktable.

tasks.longDescription: The Knowledge Inscriber works similar to the Pattern Terminal. Instead of Patterns, you need the Knowledge Core. Put in the recipe and save it to the Knowledge Core. The Knowledge Core can have 21 Recipes in it.
The Arcane Assembler just needs to be connected to the ME System for you to be able to craft the things inside of the Knowledge Core inside of it.

quests.name: Automated Automated Alchemy
quests.description: The Essentia Provider allows Thaumcraft machines to access Essentia from your ME System.

quests.name: Mirror Mirror
quests.description: The Infusion Provider allows the Infusion Altar to use Essentia from your ME System.

tasks.longDescription: The Infusion Provider has to be close to the Infusion Altar to work.
